test_metadata.test_title: Case Studies and Applied Ethics - Practice MCQ Test
test_metadata.subject: Ethics, Integrity and Aptitude
test_metadata.description: Scenario-based MCQs on applied ethics, administrative dilemmas and decision-making in public life for GS IV.

questions.question_text: You are a newly posted SDM. A local leader pressures you to overlook violations in a building project, promising political support for future postings. What is the MOST ethical course of action?

options.option_text: Agree informally to secure future career benefits
Ignore the violation since many such buildings exist
Firmly refuse, record the violations and act as per law, documenting any undue pressure
Transfer the case to a subordinate unofficially

questions.topic_tag: Political Pressure and Rule of Law

questions.question_text: A senior officer informally asks you to alter the evaluation report of a contractor to ensure the contract is renewed, hinting that 'everyone does it'. What should you MOST appropriately do?

options.option_text: Alter the report as requested to maintain good relations
Politely refuse, keep the evaluation factual and, if needed, seek written instructions
Ignore the request but do not report it
Complain anonymously without any documentation

questions.question_text: As a block development officer, you discover that your predecessor diverted a small portion of funds to complete an urgently needed village bridge, technically violating financial rules but preventing accidents. What is the MOST ethical response now?

options.option_text: Suppress all records to avoid controversy
Report the facts honestly, ensure regularisation as per rules and strengthen systems to avoid such violations in future
Ignore the issue since the outcome was good
Publicly accuse your predecessor without verifying documents

questions.question_text: A citizen from a marginalised community comes to your office with incomplete documents for a time-bound scholarship scheme. The deadline is today and she cannot arrange the missing certificate immediately. What is the MOST appropriate action?

options.option_text: Reject the application without guidance
Accept the application, give written time to submit the missing document if rules allow, and guide her properly
Ask her to pay a small amount to 'manage' the missing document
Tell her to try again next year without checking rules

questions.question_text: You’re part of a committee to shortlist beneficiaries for a housing scheme. A colleague pushes for including his distant relative who is slightly above the eligibility income limit. What is the MOST ethical option?

options.option_text: Agree silently since the relative is not very rich
Insist on strict adherence to eligibility criteria and record any dissent transparently in minutes
Leave the meeting to avoid conflict and accept the final list
Privately request the colleague to add your relative as well for 'balance'

questions.question_text: As a police officer, you find that a poor street vendor has violated licensing rules but his goods are his only livelihood. What is the MOST ethical way to respond, balancing compassion and rule of law?

options.option_text: Ignore the law completely and regularise him orally
Use minimum necessary legal action, inform him of procedures and help him access proper licensing support
Confiscate all goods harshly to 'set an example'
Take money from him and allow him to continue

questions.question_text: You are the head of a public hospital. Media reports highlight negligence in one ward. Initial inquiry suggests some lapses but exact responsibility is unclear. What should you do FIRST?

options.option_text: Deny everything publicly without checking facts
Initiate a prompt, fair inquiry, ensure patient care is immediately improved and communicate transparently
Suspend random staff members to show 'action'
Blame lack of funds and do nothing

questions.question_text: A junior officer reports to you that a senior colleague is regularly demanding bribes for issuing permits. There is no hard evidence yet, but multiple complaints exist. What is your MOST ethical response?

options.option_text: Tell the junior officer to remain silent to avoid trouble
Informally warn the senior but take no further action
Initiate discreet fact-finding, strengthen transparent processes and, if evidence emerges, proceed as per vigilance and legal procedures
Immediately publicise the allegation in media without verification

questions.question_text: As a municipal commissioner, you discover that garbage collection contracts are awarded to the same firms every year with inflated rates. What is the MOST ethical administrative step?

options.option_text: Continue as it is to avoid conflict
Order a review, redesign tender conditions transparently, and introduce competitive bidding with clear criteria
Privately ask current contractors to share profits with you
Cancel all contracts immediately without alternative arrangements

questions.question_text: You are evaluating exam answer scripts. A relative’s roll number appears in your batch. What is the MOST appropriate ethical action?

options.option_text: Award maximum marks to help your relative
Strictly follow model answers and evaluate objectively despite relation
Immediately inform the authority and request reallocation of that script to avoid conflict of interest
Give very low marks to show you are impartial

questions.question_text: In a drought-affected area, you must allocate limited water tankers between two villages: one more vocal and influential, the other more affected but less organised. What is the MOST ethical way to decide?

options.option_text: Favour the influential village to avoid protests
Divide water equally regardless of need
Assess objective need (population, severity) and allocate proportionally with clear communication
Give all tankers to the nearest village to save fuel

questions.question_text: As a senior officer, you are given a performance target that can realistically be met only if data are manipulated. What should you MOST ethically do?

options.option_text: Quietly manipulate data since others also do it
Explain ground realities to higher authorities, propose realistic targets and refuse to falsify data
Ignore the target and do nothing
Ask subordinates to adjust numbers 'slightly' so you are technically safe

questions.question_text: A private company offers to refurbish your government office free of cost in exchange for prominent advertising banners inside the office. What is the MOST ethical response?

options.option_text: Accept immediately since it reduces government expenditure
Accept informally and allow banners without any formal agreement
Examine rules on sponsorships, ensure no conflict of interest or undue influence, and proceed only through transparent, approved procedures if allowed
Reject without considering any rule or public benefit

questions.question_text: You are in charge of disaster relief distribution. A local politician insists that his supporters be given priority. Refusal may create law and order issues. What is the MOST ethical course of action?

options.option_text: Agree fully to maintain peace
Follow approved vulnerability criteria transparently, involve multiple stakeholders and seek additional security support if needed
Stop relief work completely to avoid conflict
Privately distribute extra relief to supporters only

questions.question_text: A clerk known for integrity is frequently transferred for resisting illegal orders. Staff feel demoralised. As the head of office, what is the MOST ethical action?

options.option_text: Ask the clerk to be 'practical' and cooperate
Support the clerk, document unfair transfers and raise the issue through proper channels highlighting impact on morale
Stay neutral and say it is a 'policy matter'
Discourage others from discussing such issues

questions.question_text: A teacher in a government school disciplines a student for cheating. The student's parent, a powerful local leader, pressures the teacher to change the report card. As the principal, what should you MOST ethically do?

options.option_text: Ask the teacher to change marks to avoid conflict
Stand by fair evaluation, counsel both sides and explain the importance of integrity in education
Shift blame to the teacher and remain silent
Offer to 'adjust' marks quietly in future exams instead

questions.question_text: As a district officer, you must decide on closing an old polluting industry that provides jobs to many locals. What is the MOST ethical approach to decision-making?

options.option_text: Ignore pollution because jobs are important
Order immediate closure without studying impacts or alternatives
Assess legal compliance, environmental and livelihood impacts, consult stakeholders and explore cleaner alternatives or phased transition
Wait indefinitely without taking any decision

questions.question_text: A woman complains that she was asked for a bribe to get a widow pension sanctioned. You head the relevant section. What is the MOST ethical immediate step?

options.option_text: Tell her such things are 'normal' and she should adjust
Verify her eligibility, ensure her case is processed fairly and initiate inquiry into the demand for bribe
Informally warn the staff not to get 'caught' again
Ignore the complaint as there is no written proof yet

questions.question_text: You are tasked with shortlisting NGOs for a government partnership. One NGO has excellent work record but has recently criticised government policies. What is the MOST ethical criterion to follow?

options.option_text: Reject NGOs that criticise the government
Select NGOs only based on political alignment
Use objective criteria like capacity, past performance and transparency, irrespective of criticism
Select only unknown NGOs with no track record

questions.question_text: A staff member who is usually honest has made a minor procedural mistake causing small financial loss to the department but no personal gain. What is the MOST ethical way to address this as the supervisor?

options.option_text: Ignore the mistake completely
Punish severely to 'set an example'
Acknowledge the mistake, document it, recover loss if required, and use it as a learning opportunity without being vindictive
Transfer the staff member immediately without explanation

questions.question_text: During a recruitment process you supervise, you receive an anonymous envelope with cash and a note requesting favour in interview. What is the MOST ethical step?

options.option_text: Quietly return the envelope and proceed as usual
Keep the money and still conduct a fair interview
Report the incident to higher authority or vigilance, return/secure the money as per rules, and ensure the process remains strictly merit-based
Destroy the envelope and forget about it

questions.question_text: You handle RTI applications. A politically sensitive RTI seeks information that is legally disclosable but may embarrass your department. What is the MOST ethical response?

options.option_text: Deny information citing vague 'national interest' reasons
Delay the reply as much as possible
Provide information as per RTI Act provisions, withholding only what is legitimately exempt
Ask the applicant to withdraw the request informally

questions.question_text: A subordinate regularly makes caste-based remarks about citizens. Complaints have reached you. What is the MOST ethical immediate step as head of office?

options.option_text: Ignore as 'informal talk'
Verbally ask him to be 'careful' but take no formal step
Initiate appropriate disciplinary process, counsel on equality and dignity, and make it clear such behaviour is unacceptable
Transfer complainants instead of addressing the issue

questions.question_text: As a traffic officer, your junior stops a VIP’s car for over-speeding. The VIP calls you, demanding that the challan be cancelled and the junior be 'taught a lesson'. What is the MOST ethical response?

options.option_text: Cancel the challan to avoid trouble
Rebuke the junior for stopping a VIP
Support the junior for lawful action, maintain the challan and politely explain that law is equal for all
Ignore the call and do nothing

questions.question_text: A government engineer finds that a contractor has used substandard material in a school building. Local people want the work to be accepted quickly so children can use it. What is the MOST ethical action?

options.option_text: Approve the work to satisfy locals, ignoring safety
Reject or ask for rectification as per norms, explaining safety concerns and ensuring the contractor complies
Take money from contractor and pass the work
Delay decision indefinitely

questions.question_text: You are assigned to investigate irregularities in a scheme. The main accused is known to be close to your superior. Your superior hints that a 'soft report' is expected. What is the MOST ethical course of action?

options.option_text: Write a soft report to maintain your career prospects
Conduct an impartial investigation, document evidence and submit a truthful report, seeking written instructions for any changes
Refuse to investigate without any explanation
Leak information to media without internal process

questions.question_text: As a public information officer, you discover that a file related to an RTI query has gone missing, possibly to avoid disclosure. What is the MOST ethical step?

options.option_text: Claim that the information 'never existed'
Inform the applicant honestly about missing records, initiate formal reconstruction/trace and report the loss to competent authority
Ask the applicant to withdraw RTI to avoid embarrassment
Ignore the RTI application

questions.question_text: A colleague who is your close friend routinely comes late to office but performs well overall. Other staff feel demotivated. As the section head, what is the MOST ethical way to handle this?

options.option_text: Ignore his lateness because of friendship
Apply attendance rules uniformly, counsel him privately and emphasise fairness to the team
Publicly humiliate him in front of others
Penalise other staff to compensate
None

questions.question_text: During a field visit, villagers complain that your subordinate demands bribes for issuing caste certificates. He is otherwise hardworking. What is the MOST ethical immediate step?

options.option_text: Defend him without inquiry because he is hardworking
Assure villagers of fair action, gather evidence through proper channels and, if allegations are proven, take disciplinary measures
Ask the subordinate to be more 'careful' while taking money
Transfer complaining villagers’ applications elsewhere

questions.question_text: You are part of a panel interviewing candidates from disadvantaged backgrounds. One candidate is nervous but has genuine potential, another is polished due to elite schooling. What is the MOST ethical approach to evaluation?

options.option_text: Prefer the polished candidate solely for fluent English
Consider merit holistically, including potential, context and fairness, while staying within prescribed criteria
Give full marks to disadvantaged candidate only out of sympathy
Ignore all guidelines and decide intuitively

questions.question_text: A social media post wrongly accuses your department of denying services to a community. Public anger is rising, but you know the facts are different. What is the MOST ethical first response?

options.option_text: Ignore the post completely
React angrily and threaten legal action immediately
Verify facts, issue a calm factual clarification and invite genuine complainants to contact you
Ask staff to create fake accounts and attack critics

questions.question_text: You are designing a welfare scheme portal. The IT vendor suggests hiding some complex eligibility information to 'reduce confusion', but this may mislead citizens. What is the MOST ethical decision?

options.option_text: Accept the suggestion to get the portal live quickly
Ensure all important conditions are clearly disclosed in simple language, even if it takes more effort
Publish information only in English
Share conditions only through internal circulars

questions.question_text: As a senior officer, you discover a long-standing practice of 'adjusting' travel bills slightly upward to cover unofficial office expenses (tea, stationery). Staff see it as harmless. What is the MOST ethical resolution?

options.option_text: Allow practice to continue since amount is small
Stop the practice, regularise genuine office expenses through proper budget heads and sensitise staff about financial integrity
Punish everyone harshly without explanation
Ignore as it helps office functioning

questions.question_text: A junior officer makes a courageous note opposing an illegal land allotment order by higher-ups, citing legal and ethical reasons. You are his immediate superior. What is the MOST ethical way to support him?

options.option_text: Ask him to withdraw the note to avoid controversy
Endorse his reasoning if valid, add your considered view and send it up the chain formally
Remain silent and detach your note
Advise him never to write such notes again

questions.question_text: You are managing a scholarship scheme. A deserving student missed the deadline due to a genuine medical emergency, supported by documents. Rules do not clearly mention such exceptional cases. What is the MOST ethical approach?

options.option_text: Reject strictly, ignoring all context
Explore if rules allow condonation/relaxation in exceptional cases, seek approval if needed and process transparently
Accept quietly without any record
Ask for informal payment to help the student

questions.question_text: A contractor offers to donate computers to a government school if his pending bills are cleared immediately, even though some quality issues are under examination. What is the MOST ethical response as the approving officer?

options.option_text: Accept the offer and clear bills immediately
Reject any linkage between donations and official decisions, and clear bills only after objective quality verification
Ask him to donate more in future in return for favours
Ignore quality issues and close the file

questions.question_text: You are heading an exam cell. A printing error in question paper may disadvantage some candidates. Exams are over. What is the MOST ethical immediate step?

options.option_text: Hide the error hoping no one notices
Acknowledge the error, place it before competent authority and suggest fair remedies (grace marks, re-exam, etc.)
Blame printing press publicly without internal review
Destroy the question papers to remove evidence

questions.question_text: A subordinate quietly informs you that certain senior officials have relatives as 'ghost beneficiaries' in a welfare scheme. There is partial documentary indication. What is your MOST ethical next step?

options.option_text: Ignore to avoid angering seniors
Conduct discreet verification, cross-check records and if fraud is confirmed, report through proper vigilance/administrative channels
Leak everything to social media immediately
Advise the subordinate not to interfere in seniors’ matters

questions.question_text: While compiling district performance data, you realise that including accurate data will lower the ranking of your district, which may annoy your superiors. What is the MOST ethical action?

options.option_text: Adjust figures slightly to maintain ranking
Report accurate data, highlight reasons for lower performance and suggest genuine improvement measures
Refuse to send any data
Use last year’s numbers again without change

questions.question_text: You are an investigating officer. The accused in a corruption case tries to emotionally influence you by sharing personal hardships and asks for a 'sympathetic' report. What is the MOST ethical stance?

options.option_text: Let personal hardship fully override facts and evidence
Maintain objectivity, base findings on evidence while still treating the accused with dignity
Refuse to hear any explanation
Promise to ignore incriminating evidence
None

questions.question_text: In a village meeting, women complain that they are rarely allowed to speak when development priorities are discussed. You chair the meeting. What is the MOST ethical way to handle this situation?

options.option_text: Continue as usual to avoid upsetting local customs
Explicitly encourage women to speak, ensure they get time and record their inputs fairly in decisions
End the meeting immediately
Ask women to submit written suggestions later only

questions.question_text: You are a probationer with strong ideals posted under a cynical senior who openly mocks ethical behaviour and pressures you to 'adjust'. What is the MOST ethical strategy?

options.option_text: Follow all unethical instructions to 'learn the system'
Respectfully maintain your integrity, seek guidance from training materials/mentors and politely refuse blatantly illegal acts
Constantly argue in public meetings with him
Quit the job immediately without trying any institutional remedies

questions.question_text: As the nodal officer for a vaccination drive, you notice that rural areas with weaker voice are getting fewer doses than urban centres with strong media presence. What is the MOST ethical corrective action?

options.option_text: Maintain status quo to avoid complaints from cities
Redistribute doses based on objective criteria like population, risk and vulnerability, communicating transparently
Send all doses to rural areas only
Stop vaccination in rural areas to avoid logistics issues

questions.question_text: An officer accidentally shares a draft confidential policy paper with an external academic group by email. No serious damage has occurred yet. What is the MOST ethical response?

options.option_text: Hide the mistake and hope no one finds out
Report the incident to superiors, request deletion/return, review security protocols and accept responsibility
Blame a non-existent technical glitch
Ask the academic group to keep it secret informally only

questions.question_text: You head a scholarship committee. Two candidates are tied on all criteria. One has written about commitment to public service; the other has no such indication. Rules allow limited discretion in tie cases. What is the MOST ethical use of this discretion?

options.option_text: Use discretion to favour a relative instead
Use discretion transparently to prefer the candidate with demonstrated commitment to public service, recording reasons
Flip a coin without disclosure
Ask both candidates to offer informal payments

questions.question_text: A citizen with disability finds it difficult to access your office on the second floor as there is no ramp or lift. What is the MOST ethical and practical response as the office head?

options.option_text: Ask them to send someone else on their behalf always
Immediately arrange to meet them on ground floor and initiate steps to improve accessibility infrastructure
Tell them to visit another day
State that such cases are 'rare' and no change is needed

questions.question_text: You are part of a committee to rank proposals for CSR partnership with government. A colleague argues to favour a company because it recently donated to a cultural festival you attended personally. What is the MOST ethical response?

options.option_text: Agree since the company supported culture
Clarify that ranking must be based on objective criteria and public interest, not personal gratitude
Remove competing companies without explanation
Ask the company for personal favours as well

questions.question_text: A young officer is praised in media for refusing bribes, but within the department, colleagues isolate and mock him. As his senior, what is the MOST ethical way to support him and the right values?

options.option_text: Advise him to 'compromise' to fit in
Publicly acknowledge his integrity, ensure he is not victimised and promote a culture that values honesty
Ignore the situation
Transfer him to an obscure post for 'safety'

questions.question_text: During a surprise inspection, you find that attendance registers in a remote office have been routinely filled for absent staff. The local head says 'this is how it has always been'. What is the MOST ethical course of action?

options.option_text: Accept the explanation and leave
Document the irregularity, fix responsibility, initiate corrective and disciplinary steps and introduce stricter monitoring
Ask for a share of the benefits
Destroy the registers and start fresh without any report

questions.question_text: You are drafting a note on a controversial policy with both benefits and serious risks for vulnerable groups. Political pressure favours highlighting only benefits. What is the MOST ethical way to write your note?

options.option_text: Mention only benefits and omit risks
Provide a balanced, evidence-based analysis of both benefits and risks, especially for vulnerable groups, and record your considered recommendation
Refuse to write any note
Copy an old note from another policy without change
